description: From Middle English thryven, thriven, from Old Norse þrífa (“to seize, grasp, take hold, prosper”), from Proto-Germanic *þrībaną (“to seize, prosper”), from Proto-Indo-European *trep-, *terp- (“to satisfy, enjoy”). Cognate with Swedish trivas, Danish trives, Norwegian Bokmål trives.

verbs.description: thrive (third-person singular simple present thrives, present participle thriving, simple past throve or thrived, past participle thriven or thrived)

entries.meaning: To grow or increase stature; to grow vigorously or luxuriantly, to flourish.
examples: Not all animals thrive well in captivity.

entries.meaning: To increase in wealth or success; to prosper, be profitable.
examples: Since expanding in June, the business has really thrived.
